string_table.string: Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Hello everyone! Welcome to the lecture on nonexperimental quantitative research design. This lecture is designed by Dr. Candace Chou and narrated by Dr. Karen Kozen-Lien.

Today’s topics might be a bit challenging for some people who have never conducted an experimental research before. Don’t worry, the lecture is designed to provide you the knowledge to understand experimental studies in literature and maybe use on of the experimental research designs for your own research.

By the end of the lecture, you will understand:

• Characteristics and goals of experimental research

• Experimental validity

• Types of group experimental design

• Single-subject designs

• Criteria for evaluating experimental designs

Now put aside everything else and give yourself half an hour to piece the puzzles of experimental research together.

Although nonexperimental research can provide credible findings about the relationship between variables, we might still not have a full picture of what caused what. Experimental research does provide the information about cause-and-effect outcomes. Here are a few characteristics of experimental research design:

• Researchers have direct control of an intervention (or treatment)., for example, methods of instruction, types of feedback, curricula, etc. Researchers decide on and implements a treatment for one or more groups.

• Researchers seek to control extraneous and confounding variables. For example, in the comparison of two instructional methods (the independent variable) on student class grades (dependent variable), teacher’s experience could be a confounding variable. The researchers should seek teachers of similar strengths or explain possible influence of confounding and extraneous variables on the outcomes.

• All conditions, events and procedures are the same, no systematic differences between groups.

The main goal of an experiment is to establish a cause and effect – to be able to say that the dependent variable as clearly affected only by the intervention. The challenge is the part about being able to show a change or difference, then say it’s the intervention and no something else that caused it.

Consider the cause and effect relationship the “Signal.” You want your experiment to give you the clearest signal. However the real signal is often affected by noises such as error and bias. You get only the observed signal. We can conceptualize it as the formula here on the slide.

Observed Signal = True Signal + Noise (Error + Bias)

To get the clearest signal, you need to design your experiment with three goals:

• MAXimize the systematic variation between groups or times.

• MINimize the error variance.

• CONtrol the variance due to extraneous and confounding variables.

These three goals can be put into a very compelling work: MAXMINCON.

It’s a great acronym to remember what every experiment is trying to achieve.

One way to describe the credibility and usefulness of the research findings is through validity.

There are two types of experimental validity: internal validity and external validity.

Internal validity is the extent to which the intervention, not extraneous or confounding variables, produced the observed effect. The threats to internal validity need to be eliminated.

A study is said to be strong in internal validity if extraneous and confounding variables have been identified and controlled. Extraneous and confounding variables are considered possible threats to to internal validity. Let’s take a look at the examples of the threats to internal validity in the next few slides.

Here are a few examples of threats to internal validity.

o History: These are uncontrolled events that have an effect on participants’ performance on the dependent variables. The events can occur within the study, or outside of the study.

• e.g., US goes to war with Iraq in the middle of a unit on the Middle East

o Selection: In group experiments, there can be systematic differences between groups. For example, students from a private school with strong parental support are compared with students from a public school with weak parental support.

o Maturation: These are natural changes within the participants over time. They can be physical, social, and mental development or short term changes such as fatigue, boredom, or hunger.

o Pretesting (or testing): Participants can become sensitized to the treatment as a result of a pretest. The pretest itself may influence changes.

o Instrumentation: Changes in the measures or procedures.

• e.g., One set of observers for the treatment group and a different set for the control group

o Intervention replication: In an experiment, the intervention should be repeated so each member of one group receives the same intervention separately and independently of the other members of the group. The intervention replication is a threat to internal validity to the extent that the reported number of participants is not the same as the number of replications of the intervention.

o Participant attrition (or mortality) refers to that the participants systematically drop out. This is particularly an issue with longitudinal studies

o Statistical regression refers to the tendency of groups of participants who score extremely high or low on a pretest to score closer to the mean on the post test, regardless of the effect of the intervention. It is a threat when groups are selected for research because they have high or low scores. Thus if you want to show a positive change, pick the lowest-scoring individuals, with no control or comparison group, and watch them change.

o Diffusion of treatment: Participants in the control group could be influenced by the intervention received in the treatment group. For example, a group of sixth-graders may find it resentful for not being included in the experiment group.

o Experimenter Effects: This refers to deliberate or unintended effects of the researcher. This may involve researcher bias, assumptions, or motivation to discover particular findings.

o Participant effects: These are behavioral changes that occur as a result of participation in a study. They may alter their behavior to respond more favorably.

When you review literature, use these information to critique studies that might be weak in internal validity.

Hawthorne effect is a well-known term related to participant effects.

The subjects may respond differently just because they are being studied.

The name comes from a classic study in which researchers were investigating the effect of lighting on worker productivity. As the intensity of the factory lights increased, so did the worker productivity. One researcher suggested that they reverse the treatment and lower the lights. The productivity of the workers continued to increase. It appears that being observed by the researchers was increasing productivity, not the intensity of the lights.

John Henry effect, or compensatory rivalry is another well-known term related to participant effects.

One group may view that it is in competition with the other group and may work harder than they would under normal circumstances. This generally is applied to the control group "taking on" the treatment group. The terms refers to the classic story of John Henry laying railroad track.

External validity refers to the extent to which the results can be generalized to other participants, measures, interventions, procedures, and settings. It can be from a sample to a population or other individuals, or within the sample.

For example, if a class of sixth-graders was used in an experiment and the class as a whole showed a positive gain in achievement, it may not be accurate to generalize the findings to subgroups such as the males or high-aptitude students, unless there is a specific analysis of the sub-groups. In other words, what may be true for the class as a whole may not be true for a subgroup.

Some of the internal and external validity threats are applicable to all types of research. It’s good to keep them in mind so you can address these threats when designing your own research or reviewing previous studies.

This table summarizes factors to consider in making appropriate generalizations.

These are a few factors that may be threats to external validity:

Participants: Characteristics of participants, such as SES, age, gender, race, and ability may not be true for other individuals or groups

Situation: Characteristics of the setting (e.g., Time of day; naturally occurring or contrived; surroundings) may not be applicable to those of other groups

Time: Explanations can change over time (e.g., Years or decades)

Interventions: Characteristics of the way the intervention is conceptualized and administered could change.

Measures: Nature and type of measures used to collect information might be different.

Experimental designs include four essential components:

• Interventions

• Pretest and posttests

• The number of groups in the study, and

• The presence or absence of random assignment

These components are represented with the following notation system:

R refers to random assignment

X refers to intervention (treatment; subscripts denote different interventions)

O refers to observation (pretest or posttest; subscripts denote different tests)

A, B, C, … refers to groups of participants

Please note. “Groups” refers to individuals who experience the same treatment, not intact groups.
There are many different types of experimental designs. We will focus on these six experimental designs.

Now, let’s look at single-group designs.

They are often called pre-experimental because they lack control of many variables and they have weak internal validity.

There are two single-group designs.

First, single-group posttest-only design as shown in the top diagram.

• Participants receive an intervention and take a posttest.

Second, single-group pretest-posttest design as shown in the bottom diagram.

• Participants take a pre-test, receive an intervention, and take a posttest.

• There are many threats to internal validity because of the lack of a comparison group.

An example of single-group pretest-posttest is if you want to study if the flipped learning strategy to see if it will increase student math scores. You will test student knowledge on a particular Math topic, implement the intervention, i.e., the flipped learning strategy for one semester, and then test student knowledge on the topic again to compare the score before and after.

Under the Single-group designs, the third design is called abbreviated time series design.

This design uses repeated pretests and/or posttests to improve internal validity. Suppose you want to study a new technique for increasing student attendance, which involves having teachers make targeted phone calls to the parents of students who tend to be absent. Attendance (O1) is taken each week for four weeks prior to initiating the calls. After a week of calling, attendance is taken again as shown in the diagram.

By having several “pretests,” a stable pattern of attendance can be established so that it would be unlikely that a particularly “good” or “bad” week as a pretest would influence the results.

Nonequivalent-groups posttest-only design

This design has a comparison of a control group but not a pretest. In the top graph, you can see group A has an intervention and a posttest. Group B serving as a control group receives the same posttest but no intervention.

In some nonequivalent-groups posttest-only designs, two or more groups receive different treatments as shown in the bottom diagram.

A second type of nonequivalent-groups design adds a pretest and become what is called nonequivalent-groups pretest-posttest design, also called quasi-experimental design.

In this diagram, there are two groups of participants, A and B. Group A takes the pretest (O1), receives the intervention (X1), and then take the posttest (O1). Group B takes the pretest, receives no intervention, and takes the posttest. Group B is considered the control group because it does not receive any intervention.

To put this in context, for example, a social studies teacher wants to try out a new type of praise to see if it will increase student academic performance. The teacher will use this new type of praise for the morning class and continue the same way she has been teaching with the afternoon class. The morning class is the experiment group and the afternoon class is the control group. The new type of praise is the treatment or intervention.

Quasi-experimental design is used often when participants are available in existing, or “intact,” groups, such as classes. In this example, two intact classes were used. This may create problems as the characteristics of students in these two classes might be very different. The selection of students poses a threat to the internal validity of this study. Although in one aspect, this experiment uses the same teacher, which minimize the confounding variable.

Now, Randomized-to-groups designs.

This is considered true experimental designs because the participants are first randomly assigned to the different treatment and control groups.

Random assignment means that each participant has the same probability of being in either the intervention or comparison or control group. The random assignment is to help ensure that there are no systematic differences between groups. This equalization can be assumed when a sufficient number of individuals is randomly assigned to each group (generally 15 or more).

In Randomized-to-Groups Posttest Only design, participants are first randomly assigned to the different intervention or control conditions, given the intervention (or no intervention, if control), and then given the posttest. You can also give different treatments to different groups to compare the results.

In Randomized-to-groups pretest-posttest design, a pretest is administered before the treatment. You can compare multiple groups who receive different treatments.

In most educational experiments, there is a comparison group rather than a control group because of limited resources and time to work with students, and often there is more than one comparison group.

All right, have we confused you enough on the various experimental research designs? As you come across more experimental research, keep the following criteria in mind:

• The primary purpose is to test causal hypotheses.

• There should be direct control of the intervention.

• The design should be clearly and completely described.

• The design should provide maximum control of extraneous and confounding variables.

• There should be intervention fidelity.

• The sample size should be determined by the number of independent replications of the interventions.

• The measure of the DV must be able to capture change.

• The design should be consistent with MAXMINCON.

Now, let’s review one more research design that is highly relevant to most of you, especially in special education.

Single-subject design is also called single-case experimental design.

• Researchers conduct experiments with individuals using repeated measures.

• It is commonly used in special education and counseling studies

• It provides the basis for comparison, with regard to the difference in behavior before and after treatment.

Single-subject design uses a notation system in which A refers to a baseline condition and B to a treatment condition. The order of the letters indicates the sequence of procedures in the study. Therefore, an A-B design contains one baseline and one intervention condition. In an A-B-A design, the intervention condition is followed by another baseline, as indicated in the diagram.

The A-B-A design is also called withdrawal design. The intervention is introduced after a number of observations of the baseline behavior, and is stopped to return to the same condition that was present during the original baseline measurement. The design shows a strong causal inference if the pattern of behavior changes with the addition and withdrawal of the intervention. This chart shows the results of an intervention on a student before and after the intervention.

Here are a few criteria to evaluate single-subject research:

1. There should be reliable measurement of the target behavior.

2. The target behavior should be clearly defined operationally.

3. Sufficient measurements are needed to establish stability of behavior.

4. Procedures, participants, and settings should be fully described.

5. A single, standardized intervention should be used.

6. Experimenter or observer effects should be controlled.
(Here is the last knowledge check)

In this video, we have learned different ways to conduct experimental designs via the following topics:

• Characteristics and goals of experimental research

• Experimental validity

• Types of group experimental design

• Single-subject designs

• Criteria for evaluating experimental designs
